item.title: David Cameron Pledges a ‘Full Spectrum’ Response to Tunisia Attack
item.description: The British prime minister sent security officials and ministers to the resort in Sousse, Tunisia, where 18 Britons have been confirmed among the victims.
item.dc:creator: STEPHEN CASTLE

item.title: Woman in Taiwan Dies Days After Being Burned in Water Park Blast
item.description: The 20-year-old was the first fatality from the blast on Saturday that left hundreds of people injured, with more than 200 still in intensive care.
item.dc:creator: AUSTIN RAMZY

item.title: Egypt’s Top Prosecutor Is Killed by Roadside Bomb
item.description: Hisham Barakat is the most senior official to be assassinated since insurgents began a wave of attacks against the military-backed government nearly two years ago.
item.dc:creator: KAREEM FAHIM and MERNA THOMAS
item.media:description: The site of a bomb that targeted Egypt's top prosecutor, Hisham Barakat, in Cairo, on Monday.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: The Satirical Relief After China’s Pressure-Cooker College Exam
item.description: China’s gaokao, or national college entrance exam, has inspired a new form of social commentary: Satirical essay responses that question the correct answers.
item.dc:creator: YIFU DONG
item.media:description: Chinese students celebrating with one another after completing the gaokao at Beijing Renmin University Affiliated High School on June 8.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: China Fears Loss of Great Wall, Brick by Brick
item.description: Erosion, theft and tourists are all wearing down one of China’s most famous landmarks.
item.dc:creator: EDWARD WONG
item.media:description: Scholars say the Great Wall of China is disappearing as a result of erosion, theft of bricks and damage from tourists scrambling over unrestored sections.

item.title: Burundi Holds Elections After Night of Gunfire and Grenade Attacks
item.description: Despite international calls for the postponement of parliamentary and local balloting, the government pressed ahead, saying that a delay would only add to instability.
item.dc:creator: MARC SANTORA
item.media:description: Burundians waiting to vote in parliamentary and local elections in Bujumbura, the capital, on Monday.

item.title: Greek Debt Crisis — Live Updates
item.description: News about the Greek financial crisis and its effects on the global economy.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times

item.title: Greece’s Debt Crisis Sends Stocks Falling Around Globe
item.description: Stocks slumped on Wall Street and fell sharply in Europe and Asia as Greece’s difficulties spread worries about possible broader harm to financial systems.
item.dc:creator: DAVID JOLLY and KEITH BRADSHER
item.media:description: The Nikkei 225 ended 2.9 percent lower on Monday, its weakest close since June 19.

item.title: 4 Militants Dead After Raid on Home in Eastern Pakistan, Officials Say
item.description: The authorities said they seized a huge cache of weapons in the raid, including suicide vests and five Kalashnikov rifles, along with several laptops.
item.dc:creator: WAQAR GILLANI

item.title: Israeli Navy Intercepts Ship in Flotilla Sailing Toward Gaza Strip
item.description: The vessel, which was going to protest a maritime blockade on the coastal enclave, was being led to the southern Israeli port of Ashdod, a military statement said.
item.dc:creator: DIAA HADID

item.title: Xi Hosts 56 Nations at Founding of Asian Infrastructure Bank
item.description: Many attendees at the Beijing event were American allies that Washington had urged not to join the China-led bank, seen as a rival to Western-led institutions.
item.category: Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas
item.dc:creator: JANE PERLEZ

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Dalai Lama Reflects on Aging at Glastonbury
item.description: A week ahead of his 80th birthday, the exiled Tibetan spiritual leader took to the stage at the British music festival and expressed a desire to be as active as the veteran musicians around him.
item.dc:creator: PATRICK BOEHLER

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: An Insider’s Guide to Better Eating in Chinese Detention Centers
item.description: Zheng Churan, one of the “Feminist Five” detained in March, offers a rare glimpse of the culinary offerings at China’s pretrial detention centers.
item.dc:creator: VANESSA PIAO
item.media:description: Zheng Churan, one of the five women's advocates detained last March while preparing a campaign against sex harassment on public transport.

item.title: China and India Are Sitting Out Refugee Crisis
item.description: Asia’s giants could play leadership roles but see it as a losing issue that could diminish their clout and bilateral interests.
item.category: Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas
Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees
item.dc:creator: AUSTIN RAMZY
item.media:credit: Ye Aung Thu/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Migrants found at sea were escorted across the Bangladesh border to Rakhine State in Myanmar this month. Persecution has driven thousands from Myanmar.

item.title: Polo Fades in India on the Backs of Endangered Ponies
item.description: The decline of polo and of the Manipuri pony, which was once used in warfare and is now endangered, began when state patronage for polo players ended, around the time of India’s annexation of Manipur.
item.dc:creator: IAN THOMAS JANSEN-LONNQUIST

item.title: Greece Will Shut Banks in Fallout From Debt Crisis
item.description: The prime minister’s decisions escalated tensions and uncertainty over a financial crisis that some analysts say could have global ripples.
item.dc:creator: JIM YARDLEY
item.media:description: Cabinet members applauded Greece's prime minister, Alexis Tsipras, on Sunday amid debate over a bailout referendum.

item.title: Puerto Rico’s Governor Says Island’s Debts Are ‘Not Payable’
item.description: Gov. Alejandro García Padilla said that his administration would probably seek significant concessions from its creditors on a $72 billion debt load.
item.dc:creator: MICHAEL CORKERY and MARY WILLIAMS WALSH
item.media:credit: Dennis Rivera for The New York Times
item.media:description: Gov. Alejandro García Padilla plans to discuss the island’s fiscal crisis on a televised broadcast on Monday night.

item.title: French Assailant Texted Beheading Photo to Canadian Number
item.description: French authorities said Yassine Salhi, 35, accused in the beheading and an explosion at an American chemical factory in southeastern France, used a smartphone app to send a photo of himself with the victim’s head.
item.dc:creator: ALISSA J. RUBIN and AURELIEN BREEDEN
item.media:description: French police officers on Sunday escorted Yassine Salhi, the suspect in a chemical factory attack in Saint Quentin-Fallavier.

item.title: Tunisian Gunman Showed Subtle Signs of Radicalization
item.description: Seifeddine Rezgui, the Tunisian student who shot 39 tourists at a seaside hotel on Friday, was a break-dancer in his youth but turned to extremism while in college.
item.dc:creator: CARLOTTA GALL and FARAH SAMTI
item.media:description: Tourists on Sunday placed flowers on the beach near the Imperial Marhaba hotel in Sousse, Tunisia, where a gunman killed 39 people on Friday.

item.title: Afghan President Appoints a Second Female Governor
item.description: Even though his first appointee has been unable to take office because of protests, President Ashraf Ghani picked another woman as a provincial leader.
item.dc:creator: MUJIB MASHAL and AHMAD SHAKIB
